title: Global Islamic Finance and Banking
headline: Gain an understanding of the Islamic finance and banking industry as well as Sharia law, with this online course.
description: This free online Islamic Finance course will familiarise you with the principles and frameworks of Islamic banking. Islamic banking is a form of non-interest banking based on the principles of Sharia law and ethics designed to foster a healthy society. Islamic banking is one of the fastest-growing segments within the finance sector, start this free online course today to learn about the fascinating world of Islamic finance.
courseDescription:
This course will first introduce you to Islamic finance and banking and teach you about the growth and potential for Islamic finance. You will look into the five core aims of Sharia law and learn that the Sharia law prohibits unethical, immoral, and speculative activities. The course will also discuss the Islamic perspective on wealth. You will learn the aspects of Islamic law and contracts such as types of transactions, ownership categories, and common elements of a contract.

You will then look into modes of finance including the prohibition of Riba or interest, the Prohibition of Risk (Gharar), and the Islamic insurance (Takaful). The course will discuss the difference between conventional and Islamic banks as well as the key Islamic finance products. You will also study the role of the independent Sharia boards which includes proper guidance to institutions and leading research and development programs. You will also take a look at the global regulatory environment.

This free Global Islamic Finance and Banking course covers the key concepts, services, and future of one of the fastest growing financial sectors in the world, is valued globally at more than $2 trillion USD. By taking this course, business people and government employees interested in Islamic finance and banking around the world will gain better knowledge and a deeper understanding of Islamic finance and banking. This knowledge can be highly valuable and useful, so have a look at the Islamic finance course today, and start your next learning journey.

  • The key points from this module are:
  • Islamic finance represents financial activity that is consistent with the principles of Sharia. Sharia law prohibits unethical, immoral, and speculative activities. Islamic finance encourages entrepreneurship, mutual cooperation, generosity and the spirit of partnership which connect the capital owner with real economic activities that may actually contribute to the welfare of society. For example, via construction or manufacturing.

    There is a high demand from the Muslim community for Sharia compliant alternatives to conventional finance and a lot of the concern revolves around what is allowed and what is not allowed. 

    The Sharia lays down rules that promote fair dealings in business, ethics based on universal principles which consider the needs that contribute to a healthy society.

    Sharia means a set of rules. There are five core aims or objectives of the Sharia:
    1. The preservation and protection of the religion (Deen)
    2. Protection of Life (Nafs)
    3. Progeny/Family (Nasl)
    4. The Intellect (‘Aql)
    5. Wealth (Maal)

  • The key points from this module are:
  • The primary sources of Islamic law are the Quran and the Sunnah. The Quran is the word of God and the final book revealed to mankind. The Sunnah refers to the teachings or known practices of the Prophet Muhammad which have been recorded in the volumes of Hadith literature. 

    The actions in Islam have been divided into two categories: 
    1. Ibaabaat – meaning acts of worship. This refers to actions of worship that are done solely to Allah such as prayer or fasting. 
    2. Mu’aamalaat – actions between people. This refers to how people interact with each other in their day-to-day affairs and dealings with people, such as trade or partnerships. 
  • Unlike Ibaabaat, a general principle that applies to Mu’aamalaat is that everything is allowed, except for what has been prohibited.

  • The key points from this module are:
  • The Sharia definition of the prohibition of Riba means an unlawful increase or comes from a particular transaction where the increase is not desirable. The prohibition of Riba goes against mutual cooperation, generosity, and spirit of partnership. Riba violates the entire rationale behind money and diverts money from doing what it is meant to do.

    Prohibition of Risk (Gharar) - Maisir (game of chance) is regarded as gambling because the outcome is unknown and clearly involves gharar. Gambling is an extreme form of gharar as it involves no skills, it is based on luck. 

    Takaful differs from conventional insurance. With conventional insurance, a premium is paid to transfer the risk to a third party, while in Takaful, risk is shared based on the basis of mutual help and joint responsibility. In general,  the money from contributors is placed in a pool that is used for investment, paying the Takaful operator, and most importantly, to cover the losses of contributors if they make a claim. 

    Islamic banks deal in goods and documents and not in money. Money is only used as a medium of exchange. Whereas conventional banks deal with money and documents and not in goods. Money in conventional banks is considered a commodity.

  • The key points from this module are:
  • Some of the roles of independent Sharia boards is to guide institutions and lead research and development. The scholars should always provide feedback in a safe way independently that will guide the industry and serve the community to make sure that we are always developing. 

    There are different legal and regulatory issues in different countries that will affect how much of a growth we see. Sometimes regulators are trying to protect the customer to make sure there is no transparency or loopholes.

    Technology is shaping the way we deal with money and finance through apps and virtual currency. This is showing us that how people interact with each other and with the economy and money is changing, and Islam must participate in this, not just to make it Sharia compliant, but because this is the way the economy is moving. 

    Money is the universal link between the dynamics of law, Sharia, and business. Sharia works on the principle that it only prohibits things that has a detrimental impact on the society and business etc., Sharia is trying to remove all of the issues that may cause harm to the people and leave you with a level playing field where you can compete with everyone to be the most useful to everyone.
